data.name: index_restartdesc
data.value: Click this button to activate the current Shorewall configuration with the <tt>shorewall restart</tt> command.

data.name: index_refreshdesc
data.value: Click this button to activate just the Blacklist and Traffic Shaping tables with the <tt>shorewall refresh</tt> command.

data.name: index_startdesc
data.value: Click this button to start Shorewall with the current configuration with the <tt>shorewall start</tt> command.

data.name: index_cleardesc
data.value: Click this button to clear Shorewall with the <tt>shorewall clear</tt> command. This will allow access from all hosts without restriction.

data.name: index_stopdesc
data.value: Click this button to shut down Shorewall with the <tt>shorewall stop</tt> command. This will block access from all hosts except those in the When Stopped table.

data.name: index_statusdesc
data.value: Click this button to check whether Shorewall has been started on this system, using the <tt>shorewall status</tt> command.

data.name: index_dumpdesc
data.value: Click this button to view Shorewall tracing information from the <tt>shorewall dump</tt> command.

data.name: index_checkdesc
data.value: Click this button to have Shorewall validate your firewall configuration with the <tt>shorewall check</tt> command.

data.name: list_manualdesc
data.value: Click this button to manually edit the Shorewall file $1, in which the entries above are stored.

data.name: list_ecannot
data.value: You are not allowed to edit this Shorewall table.

data.name: check_failed
data.value: .. an error was found in your firewall configuration!

data.name: zones_desc
data.value: The zones listed on this page represent different networks reachable from your system. However, the entries here do no actually have any effect on the firewall - instead, they just define zone names and descriptions.

data.name: zones_none
data.value: No network zones have been defined yet.

data.name: zones_efwid
data.value: The zone IDs $FW and fw are reserved for the firewall

data.name: policy_desc
data.value: This page allows you to configure the default actions for traffic between different firewall zones. They can be overridden for particular hosts or types of traffic on the Firewall Rules page.

data.name: policy_none
data.value: No default policies have been defined yet.

data.name: policy_efw
data.value: <Firewall> can be selected for both the source and destination zones

data.name: policy_elimit
data.value: Missing or invalid traffic limit number

data.name: policy_eburst
data.value: Missing or invalid traffic burst number

data.name: rules_desc
data.value: This table lists exceptions to the default policies for certain types of traffic, sources or destinations. The chosen action will be applied to packets matching the chosen criteria instead of the default.

data.name: rules_none
data.value: No firewall rules have been defined yet.

data.name: rules_addr
data.value: Only hosts in zone with addresses

data.name: rules_dnat
data.value: Original destination address for DNAT or REDIRECT

data.name: rules_dnat_dest
data.value: For DNAT or REDIRECT, fill in the new destination address or port here.

data.name: rules_dnat_port
data.value: For DNAT or REDIRECT, fill in the original destination port here.

data.name: rules_esinzone
data.value: No host addresses entered for source

data.name: rules_edinzone
data.value: No host addresses entered for destination

data.name: rules_esport
data.value: No source port names, numbers or ranges entered

data.name: rules_edport
data.value: No destination port names, numbers or ranges entered

data.name: rules_ednat
data.value: Original destination address must be a single IP address, two addresses separated by a :, or an exclusion list starting with !

data.name: rules_ednat2
data.value: An original destination address can only be entered for the DNAT and REDIRECT actions

data.name: tos_desc
data.value: This page defines IP service types for particular types of traffic, which can be used to raise or lower their priorities.

data.name: tos_add
data.value: Add a new type of service.

data.name: tos_none
data.value: No types of service have been defined yet.

data.name: tos_err
data.value: Failed to save type of service

data.name: interfaces_desc
data.value: Each of the network interfaces on your system that you want Shorewall to manage should be listed on this page, and associated with the zone that it is connected to. The loopback interface <tt>lo</tt> must never be listed.

data.name: interfaces_none
data.value: No network interfaces have been defined yet.

data.name: masq_desc
data.value: Entries on this page set up network address translation for traffic routed between some network and a particular interface.

data.name: masq_none
data.value: No masquerading rules have been defined yet.

data.name: masq_enet
data.value: Missing or invalid outgoing interface destination

data.name: masq_emnet
data.value: Missing or invalid masquerading subnet address

data.name: masq_eports
data.value: Missing or invalid comma-separated list of ports

data.name: nat_desc
data.value: The static network address translation entries in this table can be used to set up a 1-1 correspondence between an external address on your firewall and an RFC1918 address of a machine behind your firewall. Static NAT is often used to allow connections to an internal server from outside your network.

data.name: nat_add
data.value: Add a new static NAT entry.

data.name: nat_none
data.value: No static NAT entries have been defined yet.

data.name: nat_err
data.value: Failed to save static NAT entry

data.name: proxyarp_desc
data.value: This page allows you to configure your system to answer ARP requests for IP addresses other than its own, so that it can forward packets to those addresses to their real destinations.

data.name: proxyarp_add
data.value: Add a new proxy ARP address.

data.name: proxyarp_none
data.value: No proxy ARP addresses have been defined yet.

data.name: proxyarp_eaddr
data.value: Missing or invalid address to ARP

data.name: proxyarp_pers
data.value: Leave route even when firewall stopped?

data.name: routestopped_desc
data.value: By default, when Shorewall is stopped it will deny access from all hosts. This page allows you to define hosts or networks that will still be accessible.

data.name: routestopped_none
data.value: No addresses to be accessible when stopped have been defined yet.

data.name: tunnels_desc
data.value: This page lists VPN tunnels that pass through your firewall, and so must be allowed by the Shorewall configuration.

data.name: tunnels_none
data.value: No VPN tunnels to allow have been defined yet.

data.name: tunnels_eopenvpn
data.value: Invalid port number for OpenVPN tunnel

data.name: tunnels_egeneric
data.value: Missing protocol or protocol:port for generic tunnel

data.name: hosts_desc
data.value: This page lists hosts and networks that are part of particular zones. You generally do not need to make any changes to this list.

data.name: hosts_none
data.value: No zone hosts have been defined yet.

data.name: hosts_routestopped
data.value: Route even when firewall is stopped?

data.name: blacklist_desc
data.value: This page lists hosts and services that will be blocked if traffic from them arrives on an interface with the blacklist option set.

data.name: blacklist_none
data.value: No blacklist hosts have been defined yet.

data.name: blacklist_ehost
data.value: Missing or invalid host IP address or network address

data.name: blacklist_eports
data.value: Invalid port number or comma-separated list of ports

data.name: blacklist_eports2
data.value: Ports can only be specified for the TCP and UDP protocols

data.name: providers_desc
data.value: This page defines additional routing tables. These are needed if you have connections to more than one ISP or multiple connections to the same ISP, or run Squid as a transparent proxy on a host other than the firewall.

data.name: providers_none
data.value: No routing providers have been defined yet.

data.name: providers_emark
data.value: Missing or invalid provider mark number

data.name: route_rules_desc
data.value: The page controls which traffic is routed to the providers defined on the Additional Routing Providers page.

data.name: route_rules_none
data.value: No routing rules have been defined yet.

data.name: route_rules_epri
data.value: Rule priority must be a number

data.name: route_rules_emark
data.value: Packet mark must be in number or number/mask format

data.name: manual_desc
data.value: This form can be used to manually edit the Shorewall file $1. Be careful, as no syntax checking will be done on the changes.

data.name: acl_nochange
data.value: Can apply, stop and start Shorewall configuration?

data.name: opts_source
data.value: Allow from host to any destination

data.name: opts_dest
data.value: Allow to host from any source

data.name: opts_arp_filter
data.value: Only respond to ARP requests for interface IP

data.name: opts_detectnets
data.value: Taylor zone to include only routed hosts

data.name: log_up_table
data.value: Moved up entry in the $1 table

data.name: log_down_table
data.value: Moved down entry in the $1 table

data.name: shorewall_conf_desc
data.value: This page allows you to configure the global configuration variables. NOTE: Changing the order of variables here is not recommended if you wish to preserve the relative position of comments in the configuration file.

data.name: shorewall_conf_varname
data.value: Invalid variable name (must be a valid shell variable name)

data.name: params_desc
data.value: This page allows you to configure Shorewall's custom parameters. NOTE: Changing the order of parameters here is not recommended if you wish to preserve the relative position of comments in the configuration file.

data.name: params_varname
data.value: Invalid parameter name (must be a valid shell variable name)
